articles.headline: Making Economics Relevant Again
articles.snippet: Economics has got its groove back. Who are the economists doing influential work on crucial questions facing modern society today?
articles.abstract: Economics has got its groove back. Who are the economists doing influential work on crucial questions facing modern society today?
articles.lead_paragraph: It was only a decade ago that economics seemed to be an old and tired discipline. The field no longer had intellectual giants like John Maynard Keynes or Milton Friedman who were shaping public policy by the sheer force of their ideas. Instead, it was devolving into a technical discipline that was even less comprehensible than it was relevant.

articles.headline: Slowdown Hits Towns at Outskirts of Texas Boom
articles.snippet: Texas as a whole is booming, but across the state’s outermost exurbs, building has ground almost to a halt.
articles.abstract: Texas as a whole is booming, but across the state’s outermost exurbs, building has ground almost to a halt.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAVON, Tex.  Once little more than a speed trap 25 miles northeast of Dallas, this town started to boom about a year ago, as turreted stone castlettes and modest brick bungalows began springing up in what had been wheat fields.

articles.headline: Pakistan Victors Want Dialogue With Militants
articles.snippet: The winners of the parliamentary elections said that they would take a new approach to fighting Islamic militants.
articles.abstract: The winners of the parliamentary elections said that they would take a new approach to fighting Islamic militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The winners of Pakistan’s parliamentary elections said Tuesday that they would take a new approach to fighting Islamic militants by pursuing more dialogue than military confrontation, and that they would undo the crackdown on the media and restore independence to the judiciary.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Castro Quits One Role, but May Not Be Done Yet
articles.snippet: The announcement that Fidel Castro would step down opens the door to his brother Raúl or another member of his inner circle.
articles.abstract: The announcement that Fidel Castro would step down opens the door to his brother Raúl or another member of his inner circle.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA  Fidel Castro, bedridden for 19 months, on Tuesday gave up the almost unlimited power he has wielded in Cuba for nearly 50 years, but whether the surprise announcement represented a historic change or a symbolic political maneuver remained unclear.

articles.headline: Driving to the Gold Rush
articles.snippet: Leaving jobs at global giants, small miners are striking out for Mexico’s Sierra Madre mountains.
articles.abstract: Leaving jobs at global giants, small miners are striking out for Mexico’s Sierra Madre mountains.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAGUARICHIC, Mexico  In these mountains, where conquistadors once gouged gold from open veins in the mountainside, the hardened gold miner of film lore is giving way to a new breed of prospector: geologists and engineers, armed with sophisticated equipment and millions of investor dollars.

articles.headline: Tax Inquiry? Principality Is Offended
articles.snippet: After weathering days of criticism from Germany over a spectacular tax evasion case, Liechtenstein is digging in to defend its lucrative tradition of banking secrecy.
articles.abstract: After weathering days of criticism from Germany over a spectacular tax evasion case, Liechtenstein is digging in to defend its lucrative tradition of banking secrecy.
articles.lead_paragraph: VADUZ, Liechtenstein  It’s not exactly the “mouse that roared,” though maybe the mouse that resisted.
articles.byline: By Eric Pfanner and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Auctions Yield Chaos for Bonds
articles.snippet: As municipal bond auctions fail, it is becoming clear that the auction-rate market is in crisis and chaos, and many securities may never have a successful auction again.
articles.abstract: As municipal bond auctions fail, it is becoming clear that the auction-rate market is in crisis and chaos, and many securities may never have a successful auction again.
articles.lead_paragraph: As municipal bond auctions continue to fail  and to produce very odd interest rates when they succeed  it is becoming clear that the auction-rate market is in crisis and chaos, and many securities may never have a successful auction again.

articles.headline: Lacking Cure, a New Tack on a Muscle Disease
articles.snippet: Rather than concentrate only on a cure for a common form of muscular dystrophy, researchers are now intent on alleviating its effects.
articles.abstract: Rather than concentrate only on a cure for a common form of muscular dystrophy, researchers are now intent on alleviating its effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than four decades, on telethons featuring celebrity performers and children in wheelchairs, Jerry Lewis has been raising money each Labor Day for the Muscular Dystrophy Association and the disease that helped make “poster child” part of the American idiom.

articles.headline: Supply Fears Push Oil to Triple Digits
articles.snippet: Crude oil vaulted through a longstanding psychological barrier amid persistent concern about whether production can keep up with rising global demand.
articles.abstract: Crude oil vaulted through a longstanding psychological barrier amid persistent concern about whether production can keep up with rising global demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Crude oil closed above $100 a barrel for the first time Tuesday, vaulting through a longstanding psychological barrier amid persistent concern about whether production can keep up with rising global demand.

articles.headline: Obama Extends Streak to 10 and Makes Inroads Among Women
articles.snippet: With decisive victories in Wisconsin and Hawaii, Barack Obama cut into Hillary Rodham Clinton’s support among women and union members.
articles.abstract: With decisive victories in Wisconsin and Hawaii, Barack Obama cut into Hillary Rodham Clinton’s support among women and union members.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama decisively beat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the Wisconsin primary and the Hawaii caucuses on Tuesday night, accelerating his momentum ahead of crucial primaries in Ohio and Texas and cutting into Mrs. Clinton’s support among women and union members.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Ending Tradition, NBC Dismisses Fall Debuts
articles.snippet: NBC Universal’s move to a year-round schedule of staggered program debuts could alter an American cultural cycle that dates to the days of radio.
articles.abstract: NBC Universal’s move to a year-round schedule of staggered program debuts could alter an American cultural cycle that dates to the days of radio.
articles.lead_paragraph: It soon may be time to retire the phrase “fall television season.”
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Stuart Elliott

articles.headline: Stumping for Shelf Space
articles.snippet: The makers of Guru energy drinks are trying to crack New York City’s crowded beverage market.
articles.abstract: The makers of Guru energy drinks are trying to crack New York City’s crowded beverage market.
articles.lead_paragraph: CRAIG MARGULIES is hoping to strike it rich in the grab-and-go beverage cases on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
